<div id="tab-description" class="plugin-description section">
	<h2 id="description-header">Description</h2>
	<p>This is <strong>BETA</strong> software, see the FAQ to see the current feature set or rather what is still planned.</p>
<p>The plugin implements the ActivityPub protocol for your blog. Your readers will be able to follow your blogposts on Mastodon and other federated platforms that support ActivityPub.</p>
<p>The plugin works with the following federated platforms:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://joinmastodon.org/" rel="nofollow ugc">Mastodon</a></li>
<li><a href="https://pleroma.social/" rel="nofollow ugc">Pleroma</a></li>
<li><a href="https://friendi.ca/" rel="nofollow ugc">Friendica</a></li>
<li><a href="https://hubzilla.org/" rel="nofollow ugc">HubZilla</a></li>

</ul></div>

<div id="tab-installation" class="plugin-installation section">
	<h2 id="installation-header">Installation</h2>
	<p>Follow the normal instructions for <a href="https://wordpress.org/support/article/managing-plugins/">installing WordPress plugins</a>.</p>
<h4>Automatic Plugin Installation</h4>
<p>To add a WordPress Plugin using the <a href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Administration_Screens#Add_New_Plugins" rel="nofollow ugc">built-in plugin installer</a>:</p>
<ol>
<li>Go to <a href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Administration_Screens#Plugins" rel="nofollow ugc">Plugins</a> > <a href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Plugins_Add_New_Screen" rel="nofollow ugc">Add New</a>.</li>
<li>Type “<code>activitypub</code>” into the <strong>Search Plugins</strong> box.</li>
<li>Find the WordPress Plugin you wish to install.
<ol>
<li>Click <strong>Details</strong> for more information about the Plugin and instructions you may wish to print or save to help setup the Plugin.</li>
<li>Click <strong>Install Now</strong> to install the WordPress Plugin.</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>The resulting installation screen will list the installation as successful or note any problems during the install.</li>
<li>If successful, click <strong>Activate Plugin</strong> to activate it, or <strong>Return to Plugin Installer</strong> for further actions.</li>
</ol>
<h4>Manual Plugin Installation</h4>
<p>There are a few cases when manually installing a WordPress Plugin is appropriate.</p>
<ul>
<li>If you wish to control the placement and the process of installing a WordPress Plugin.</li>
<li>If your server does not permit automatic installation of a WordPress Plugin.</li>
<li>If you want to try the <a href="https://github.com/pfefferle/wordpress-activitypub" rel="nofollow ugc">latest development version</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p>Installation of a WordPress Plugin manually requires FTP familiarity and the awareness that you may put your site at risk if you install a WordPress Plugin incompatible with the current version or from an unreliable source.</p>
<p>Backup your site completely before proceeding.</p>
<p>To install a WordPress Plugin manually:</p>
<ul>
<li>Download your WordPress Plugin to your desktop.
<ul>
<li>Download from <a href="https://wordpress.org/plugins/activitypub/">the WordPress directory</a></li>

</ul>
</li>

<li>With your FTP program, upload the Plugin folder to the <code>wp-content/plugins</code> folder in your WordPress directory online.</li>
<li>Go to <a href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Administration_Screens#Plugins" rel="nofollow ugc">Plugins screen</a> and find the newly uploaded Plugin in the list.</li>

<div id="faq" class="plugin-faq section">
	<h2 id="faq-header">FAQ</h2>
	<dl>
<dt id='what%20is%20the%20status%20of%20this%20plugin%3F'>
<h3>What is the status of this plugin?</h3>
</dt>
<dd>
<p>Implemented:</p>
<ul>
<li>profile pages (JSON representation)</li>
<li>custom links</li>
<li>functional inbox/outbox</li>
<li>follow (accept follows)</li>
<li>share posts</li>
<li>receive comments/reactions</li>
</ul>
<p>To implement:</p>
<ul>
<li>signature verification</li>
<li>better WordPress integration</li>
<li>better configuration possibilities</li>
<li>threaded comments support</li>
</ul>
</dd>
<dt id='what%20is%20%22activitypub%20for%20wordpress%22'>
<h3>What is “ActivityPub for WordPress”</h3>
</dt>
<dd>
<p><em>ActivityPub for WordPress</em> extends WordPress with some Fediverse features, but it does not compete with platforms like Friendica or Mastodon. If you want to run a <strong>decentralized social network</strong>, please use <a href="https://joinmastodon.org/" rel="nofollow ugc">Mastodon</a> or <a href="https://gnusocial.network/" rel="nofollow ugc">GNU social</a>.</p>
</dd>
<dt id='what%20are%20the%20differences%20between%20this%20plugin%20and%20pterotype%3F'>
<h3>What are the differences between this plugin and Pterotype?</h3>
</dt>
<dd>
<p><strong>Compatibility</strong></p>
<p><em>ActivityPub for WordPress</em> is compatible with OStatus and IndieWeb plugin suites. <em>Pterotype</em> is incompatible with the standalone <a href="https://wordpress.org/plugins/webfinger/">WebFinger plugin</a>, so it can’t be run together with OStatus.</p>
<p><strong>Custom tables</strong></p>
<p><em>Pterotype</em> creates/uses a bunch of custom tables, <em>ActivityPub for WordPress</em> only uses the native tables and adds as little meta data as possible.</p>
</dd>
<dt id='what%20if%20you%20are%20running%20your%20blog%20in%20a%20subdirectory%3F'>
<h3>What if you are running your blog in a subdirectory?</h3>
</dt>
<dd>
<p>In order for webfinger to work, it must be mapped to the root directory of the URL on which your blog resides.</p>
<p><strong>Apache</strong></p>
<p>Add the following to the .htaccess file in the root directory:</p>
<pre><code>RedirectMatch "^\/\.well-known(.*)$" "\/blog\/\.well-known$1"
</code></pre>
<p>Where ‘blog’ is the path to the subdirectory at which your blog resides.</p>
<p><strong>Nginx</strong></p>
<p>Add the following to the site.conf in sites-available:</p>
<pre><code>location ~* /.well-known {
    allow all;
    try_files $uri $uri/ /blog/?$args;
}
</code></pre>
<p>Where ‘blog’ is the path to the subdirectory at which your blog resides.</p>
</dd>
</dl></div>

This is BETA software, see the FAQ to see the current feature set or rather what is still planned.

The plugin implements the ActivityPub protocol for your blog. Your readers will be able to follow your blogposts on Mastodon and other federated platforms that support ActivityPub.

The plugin works with the following federated platforms:

  • Mastodon
  • Pleroma
  • Friendica
  • HubZilla
  • Pixelfed
  • SocialHome
  • Misskey

Follow the normal instructions for installing WordPress plugins.

Automatic Plugin Installation

To add a WordPress Plugin using the built-in plugin installer:

  1. Go to Plugins > Add New.
  2. Type “activitypub” into the Search Plugins box.
  3. Find the WordPress Plugin you wish to install.
    1. Click Details for more information about the Plugin and instructions you may wish to print or save to help setup the Plugin.
    2. Click Install Now to install the WordPress Plugin.
  4. The resulting installation screen will list the installation as successful or note any problems during the install.
  5. If successful, click Activate Plugin to activate it, or Return to Plugin Installer for further actions.

Manual Plugin Installation

There are a few cases when manually installing a WordPress Plugin is appropriate.

  • If you wish to control the placement and the process of installing a WordPress Plugin.
  • If your server does not permit automatic installation of a WordPress Plugin.
  • If you want to try the latest development version.

Installation of a WordPress Plugin manually requires FTP familiarity and the awareness that you may put your site at risk if you install a WordPress Plugin incompatible with the current version or from an unreliable source.

Backup your site completely before proceeding.

To install a WordPress Plugin manually:

  • Download your WordPress Plugin to your desktop.
    • Download from the WordPress directory
    • Download from GitHub
  • If downloaded as a zip archive, extract the Plugin folder to your desktop.
  • With your FTP program, upload the Plugin folder to the wp-content/plugins folder in your WordPress directory online.
  • Go to Plugins screen and find the newly uploaded Plugin in the list.
  • Click Activate to activate it.

What is the status of this plugin?

Implemented:

  • profile pages (JSON representation)
  • custom links
  • functional inbox/outbox
  • follow (accept follows)
  • share posts
  • receive comments/reactions

To implement:

  • signature verification
  • better WordPress integration
  • better configuration possibilities
  • threaded comments support

What is “ActivityPub for WordPress”

ActivityPub for WordPress extends WordPress with some Fediverse features, but it does not compete with platforms like Friendica or Mastodon. If you want to run a decentralized social network, please use Mastodon or GNU social.

What are the differences between this plugin and Pterotype?

Compatibility

ActivityPub for WordPress is compatible with OStatus and IndieWeb plugin suites. Pterotype is incompatible with the standalone WebFinger plugin, so it can’t be run together with OStatus.

Custom tables

Pterotype creates/uses a bunch of custom tables, ActivityPub for WordPress only uses the native tables and adds as little meta data as possible.

What if you are running your blog in a subdirectory?

In order for webfinger to work, it must be mapped to the root directory of the URL on which your blog resides.

Apache

Add the following to the .htaccess file in the root directory:

RedirectMatch "^\/\.well-known(.*)$" "\/blog\/\.well-known$1"

Where ‘blog’ is the path to the subdirectory at which your blog resides.

Nginx

Add the following to the site.conf in sites-available:

location ~* /.well-known {
    allow all;
    try_files $uri $uri/ /blog/?$args;

Automatic Plugin Installation
To add a WordPress Plugin using the built-in plugin installer:

What is the status of this plugin?


Implemented:

profile pages (JSON representation)

To implement:

What is “ActivityPub for WordPress”


ActivityPub for WordPress extends WordPress with some Fediverse features, but it does not compete with platforms like Friendica or Mastodon. If you want to run a decentralized social network, please use Mastodon or GNU social.


What are the differences between this plugin and Pterotype?


Compatibility
ActivityPub for WordPress is compatible with OStatus and IndieWeb plugin suites. Pterotype is incompatible with the standalone WebFinger plugin, so it can’t be run together with OStatus.
Custom tables
Pterotype creates/uses a bunch of custom tables, ActivityPub for WordPress only uses the native tables and adds as little meta data as possible.


What if you are running your blog in a subdirectory?


In order for webfinger to work, it must be mapped to the root directory of the URL on which your blog resides.
Apache
Add the following to the .htaccess file in the root directory:
RedirectMatch "^\/\.well-known(.*)$" "\/blog\/\.well-known$1"

Where ‘blog’ is the path to the subdirectory at which your blog resides.
Nginx
Add the following to the site.conf in sites-available:
location ~* /.well-known {
    allow all;
    try_files $uri $uri/ /blog/?$args;
}

Where ‘blog’ is the path to the subdirectory at which your blog resides.
